dsDescriptionValue.value: How does segregation shape inter-group violence in contested urban spaces? Should nominal rivals be kept separate, or instead more closely integrated? We develop an empirically grounded agent-based model to understand the sources and patterns of violence in urban areas, employing Jerusalem as a demonstration case and seeding our model with micro-level, geocoded data on settlement patterns. An optimal set of parameters is selected to best fit the observed spatial distribution of violence in the city, with the calibrated model used to assess how different levels of segregation, reflecting various proposed “virtual futures” for Jerusalem, would shape violence. Our results suggest that besides spatial proximity, social distance is key to explaining conflict over urban areas: arrangements conducive to reducing the extent of inter-group interactions—including localized segregation, limits on mobility and migration, partition, and differentiation of political authority—can be expected to dampen violence, although the effect of these structural changes depends decisively on social distance.

publicationCitation.value: Bhavnani, Ravi, Karsten Donnay, Dan Miodownik, Maayan Mor, and Dirk Helbing. 2014. “Group Segregation and Urban Violence.” American Journal of Political Science 58 (1): 226–45.

producerAffiliation.value: International Relations and Political Science, Graduate Institute of International Studies, 11 A Avenue de la Paix, Geneva, 1211, SWITZERLAND

value: Data on acts of violence involving Secular/Moderate Orthodox Jews, Ultra-Orthodox Jews, Palestinians and (Israeli) security forces within the municipal boundaries of Jerusalem. Also includes data on several permanent checkpoints in the outskirts of the city, which are used to control population flows between the West Bank and the city. Data is spatially and/or temporally aggregated at the resolution used in the study. Further, yearly population data by neighborhood of Jerusalem and shape files containing geographic information on the neighborhoods of Jerusalem and on the general locations of dwellings in the city.
Population groups of Jerusalem, specifically Palestinians, Ultra-Orthodox Jews, Secular/Moderate-Orthodox Jews, and Israeli security forces.

files.description: Shape file containing approximate locations of dwellings within the city.
files.label: JM_Dwelling_Locations.zip

dataFile.description: Shape file containing approximate locations of dwellings within the city.

files.description: Data on the number of times a violent incident involved group A as perpetrator and group B as victim,  aggregated across the whole city; data is given both yearly and for the two distinct periods considered in the study (2001-04, 2005-09). Categories are labeled as 'AvsB' where abbreviations are as follows: S: Secular/Moderate-Orthodox Jews, U: Ultra-Orthodox Jews, P: Palestinians, F: Security Forces.
files.label: JM_Incidents_by_Group.tab

dataFile.description: Data on the number of times a violent incident involved group A as perpetrator and group B as victim,  aggregated across the whole city; data is given both yearly and for the two distinct periods considered in the study (2001-04, 2005-09). Categories are labeled as 'AvsB' where abbreviations are as follows: S: Secular/Moderate-Orthodox Jews, U: Ultra-Orthodox Jews, P: Palestinians, F: Security Forces.

files.description: Aggregate counts of violent incidents for each of the city's 79 neighborhoods in the two distinct periods considered in this study (2001-04, 2005-09).
files.label: JM_Incidents_by_Neighborhood.tab

dataFile.description: Aggregate counts of violent incidents for each of the city's 79 neighborhoods in the two distinct periods considered in this study (2001-04, 2005-09).

files.description: Yearly population data (2001-2008) for each of the city's 79 neighborhoods disaggregated by population group (Palestinians, Ultra-Orthodox Jews, Secular/Moderate-Orthodox Jews).
files.label: JM_Neighborhood_Population.tab

dataFile.description: Yearly population data (2001-2008) for each of the city's 79 neighborhoods disaggregated by population group (Palestinians, Ultra-Orthodox Jews, Secular/Moderate-Orthodox Jews).

files.description: Shape file containing the location and shapes of the city's 79 neighborhoods.
files.label: JM_Neighborhoods.zip

dataFile.description: Shape file containing the location and shapes of the city's 79 neighborhoods.
